question: Is it a sufficiently complicated problem, being able to reason your way through solving that problem?
If I show you a painting, it's a bunch of colors on a canvas, what does it mean to you?
Can we come up with if we had a big body of knowledge, something in the order of several terabytes?
So the decision to buzz in and then the actual answering, are those two different stages?
Why wouldn't we take this grand challenge and push it as hard as we can?
If you could go to the web, do you think that problem is solvable, if you just pause on it?
Just thinking even beyond jeopardy, do you think the problem of reading text to find where the answer is?
I'm sure there's a lot of day to day breakthroughs, but was there a breakthrough that really helped improve performance?
Do you see free-flowing dialogue as fundamentally more difficult than question answering, even with shared interpretation?
What timeline, year will society have something that you would be comfortable calling an artificial general intelligence system?
